Journal Story: Mile 137.0 to 143.7 First day back on the trail. Mom and Brenda dropped me off at the trail at 9:15. What a climb out of the Nantahala Outdoor Center -- 3000 ft. Took me 5.5 hours to hike 6.9 miles. Rain was in the forecast but only sprinkles after 8am. Staying at Sassafras Gap Shelter which is packed tonite because rain is predicted. Big shelter but very dirty. Wish I was in my tent.

Mile 143.7 to 150.4
Got hardly any sleep last nite. Had to get up 3 times for a nature call. I know that was just because I wasn't sleeping. We had a brief rain shower around 10:30 but when I got up later the sky was full of stars. Trapper John said a mouse dropped on his face in the middle of the nite and he just laughed. I told him if that had happened to me the whole shelter and everyone camped nearby would have heard me screaming.Lots of up and downs today but not a huge elevation change like yesterday. It started raining around 12:15 but I didn't put on my rain gear or my pack cover because I thought it would stop like yesterday. I was wrong so after at least 1/2 hr. I finally found a place to stop and put them on. But I was already wet and so was the pack.Before I started hiking this morning I made a reservation at the Cabin in the Woods. Donna, one of the owners, picked me up at 4:30 and I'm sharing a cabin with Memo and Bruce, two sisters from CO and CA. Right now it's thundering, lightening and raining really hard. Glad I decided to stay here tonite. There will be a lot of soaked hikers tomorrow!

Mm 150.4 to 158.9
Last nite it stormed for about 2.5 hrs. Lots of rain, thunder and lightning. I fell asleep while it was still storming...warm and cozy at The Cabin in the Woods. Donna and Phil are wonderful hosts. Donna made us breakfast sandwiches to take to the trail that were delicious. Started out ascending as usual. Before I knew it I was in Jacob's Ladder. It's a very steep section of trail. There are no signs saying when it starts and ends but I'd guess it's about a mile. There were another couple long ascents and then the trail leveled off a bit. The weather was 70s with beautiful sunshine and a cool breeze. Met several thru hikers...Popeye, Solomon, Scout and several more. Got to the shelter at 4:30 -- made good time today since I didn't start until 10:30. Great day on the trail...one of the best I've ever had. No cell service tonite. Think I'll read until I fall asleep.

Mm 158.9 to 164
More uphill as soon as I leave the shelter. Headed to Fontana Village to pick up a dropbox and spend the nite. The weather is great again today. I saw my first snake for this year. Don't know what kind it is but it wss only 18" long. I went around and it slithered across the trail. At one point I got to the top of the mountain and saw Fontana Lake way below. It"s quite a sight -- beautiful clear blue.My feet were aching by the time I arrived at Rt. 28 where a shuttle will take hikers into Fontana. There is a phone at the restrooms that you can use to call for the shuttle and for $3 they come pick you up. Fontana is very hiker friendly...Lots of hikers have a dropbox sent there and stay at the Inn. They also have good resupply items. Checked in and got my dropbox then Gadget Legs and I went to the Pitstop for lunch. Kate gave us a ride down the hill and we enjoyed hotdogs and nachos. Luckily we got another shuttle ride back up to my room. Gadget Legs had been doing a section hike and was leaving the trail today. Amazingly a friend of hers had driven in to meet here and when Gadget got to the Inn and got a cell signal they connected and they left. I showered and dried out my tent since we had a heavy dew last nite and I had to take it down very damp. Had a salad for dinner and made phone calls.Didn't sleep well because the air conditioner in the room next door ran all nite. I finally turned on the TV to drown out the noise.

Zero Day
Went to do laundry at 8am when the laundromat opened. Didn't realize I needed to get change and detergent at the general store next door which didn't open until 9am. So didn't get done until 10:30. Decided to take a zero because I was tired and wasn't even packed up yet.It was a productive day because I reworked how I wanted to hike the GSMNP (Great Smokey Mtn. Natl. Park). Each hiker must have a permit which is good for 8 days and 7 nights and I was concerned about finishing in that time. You must stay at the shelters which limits your options. So I relaxed and figured out how to accomplish the next 71 miles.Feeling much better both physically and mentally!

Mm. 264.4_171.8
WOW it...What a climb today. I was on the trail by 8:15 because I asked Kate, the shuttle driver, to pick me up at 8:00. It rained and stormed last night but I didn't hear it. It was still sprinkling when I started hiking. Walked by the "Fontana Hilton" which is the shelter for the area. It holds 20 hikers, has a restroom, shower, and charging station. Visited for a few minutes and took some pics. Then walked across Fontana Dam and up Shuckstack Mountain (2100' ascent). It had stopped raining but was very windy which made it cold. Don't know how cold but probably in the 40s. My phone hadn't shut off after taking pics and the battery died. I thought I had 13 hrs. of battery life on this new phone...I guess not. No pics or communication until Gatlinburg in 4 days.
Hiked the .1 mi. up to the Shuckstack fire tower but it looked too rickety to climb. Mom and I had hiked Shuckstack 10-12 yrs. ago and it was just as hard this time as it was then.
I'm now in GSMNP where I have to stay in shelters or campsites. When I arrived at Birch Spring Gap campsite the wind was really blowing up thru the gap but I had to stay because the next shelter was more than 5 mi. further and I was too tired. The wind has died down a little but it's going to be cold tonight.

Mm 180.1-189.0Rained a little in the nite so packed up wet...May have just been heavy dew. Nothing of note happened today. Dried out tent while eating lunch at Mollies Ridge Shelter. It was foggy until noon and then sunny and warm.Slept in the shelter tonite and no mouse encounters. The wind was howling until 10pm then it completely? stopped. The shelter has tarps covering the open side but they had some holes, so I was glad the wind calmed.

Talked to Mom this morning. Hickory loaned me his phone since mine is dead. Very warm and sunny today. Put on sunscreen but got burned in the areas I missed. There was no shade on the trail because the trees don't have leaves yet. It was a long hard day--lots of ups and downs. I had taken 2 allergy pills this morning because the pollen is kinda bad. That really dried me up which was great but I ran out of water. The last mile took me almost an hour to do and when I walked into the shelter I immediately asked for water which Momentum gladly supplied. Then Tarzan (who I'd never met) offered to go fill up my water bottle. Momentum said better take him up on that offer because the creek was a little ways. I gladly accepted. Thank you both!!!
It's cold and windy again tonite and I think it's blowing in rain. Slept in my tent since the shelter is full. I was so tired that I didn't pay attention to which way the wind was blowing when I pitched my tent (actually I wasn't sure which way to pitch it because the wind was sorta swirling) and I picked the wrong direction. Wind bombarded the side of my tent all nite. It held though...And I was warm and comfy.

Mile marker 189.0 - 194.7
The wind howled all nite last night. I had pitched my tent the wrong way but it withstood the wind all night. I was cozy and warm but didn't sleep much because of the wind blowing on my tent? first in one direction then the other. It started raining at 8:00 so I decided to wait to pack up and see if it would stop and it did. So I was half done when it started to rain again. I had my tent halfway doen so I finished quickly and grabbed everything and ran to the shelter. By that time every thing was wet and I still had to finish getting it in the pack. What a mess. It rained the whole day and I ended up hiking in thunder and lightning part of the time. I got to Siler Bald Shelter at 2:45 but had planned to continue to the next shelter. I was soaked even tho I had on my rain gear. Someone asked me to come in and get warm. I walked in and the shelter was already full but they had a big fire going in the fireplace. I've never seen so much wet gear hung all over the place. The guys were tightening up the tarps so the rain and wind wouldn't get in.  There were 2 section hikers expected who had reservations so I knew I had to leave since it was already full. Several hikers moved closer together and made room for me and told me not to go back out in the rain. I was so grateful!!Everyone dried out our footwear and as many clothes as possible. It took all evening and most of the night for all of us to get clothes dry enough to put on in the morning. The guys kept wood cut for the fire and Rock Star got water for all of us--he made 2 trips for some of us. The fire kept us warm all nite and we took turns stoking it all nite. I did a 3:15-4:00am stint. I had woken up at 3am and couldn't get back to sleep so I relieved the hiker watching the fire. Went back to bed and slept very soundly until 6:30am.

Started out hiking with 2nd Dinner. We had met several times at shelters. Again, she hikes faster than me but she waited for me at Clingman's Dome. 
On my way up the mountain I passed 2 women hikers. The second one said "I know you." I didn't recognize her but come to find out she (Ziplock) and Repack were on the trail in 2015 the day we all came out of Hiawassee and we leapfrogged most of that day. I was having trouble with my ankle and they remembered me. Incredible that I would run into them hiking southbound from Clingman's Dome. They've been doing sections since that time too. It's true...You never know who you'll run into on the trail.
It was a challenging climb but made it by 12:30. We hitched into town and a great couple (Terry and Jennifer from Michigan) gave us a ride. They were staying at the Econolodge and since we didn't have any hotel reservation we just had them take us there. Great hotel for $62+tax. We showered and then Terry and Jennifer took us to the Food Lion to resupply. Thanks so much Terry and Jennifer...Real trail angels!!!We had pizza at the Mello Mushroom and by the time we were finished eating we were exhausted so just relaxed the rest of the evening. Laundry will have to wait until tomorrow.

Taking a zero today. Storms are predicted tonight so I'm staying put. Ate sausage, and biscuits and gravy for breakfast at the motel. Yum!! Then went to the laundromat. They have a great trolley system here and for 50 cents you can get around easily. Went to the Dollar Store for sunscreen then 2nd Dinner and I ate lunch at McDonald's. I had a bacon ranch salad...It was so good. As we were walking to catch the trolley 2 women in a van stopped and asked us if we were hikers. They offered us a ride back into town. Turns out they are also hikers and one of them is recovering from an injury and they had hooked up with a ministry in town who had loaned them the van to provide rides for hikers. They offered to take us back to Clingman's Dome tomorrow so we'll let them know what time. That's great since the shuttle driver 2nd Dinner had called was going to charge $70.
We just ate leftover pizza for dinner and then walked around town. Not nearly as many people out tonight, probably because storms are expected.

Didn't sleep much last night. 2nd Dinner and I had decided to go back to the trail today and I was worried about that decision. Slept about 3 hrs. after deciding not to start today. 
In the morning 2nd Dinner made the same decision. After breakfast we walked to the outfitter's. We had found out that the road to Clingman's Dome was closed due to ice and snow so we couldn't have started there anyhow. We bought a few things we needed and went to Bennett's BBQ. Then went back to the motel and took a nap. Stayed in the rest of the day since it had rained all day and relaxed.

It had stopped raining in the night. The road to Clingman's Dome is still closed. We had to change motels because the Econolodge and many of the motels were booked due to a car show in Pigeon Forge. After breakfast we walked across the street to the Gillette Motel and we're in a our new room by 10:00. This is a family owned motel, older but nice. We had to pay $89.00 but this was the weekend rate I'm sure.
Noel, a hiker from Australia that I hiked with last year arrived in town overnight, so 2nd Dinner and I met him for a late lunch. We met at the outfitter's. And went to Blaine's to eat. Good food. Lots of hikers in town.
The sun was out but still cool out. The road to Clingman's Dome is still closed. All 3 of us will head back out in the morning. I'm skipping the 7 miles from Clingman's Dome to Newfound Gap. I'll do those in the fall. Went back to the room and packed and showered and relaxed. There will be lots of hikers going back in the morning so will see lots of people. Hope the road to Clingman's Dome is back open so the thruhikers can continue on and not have to worry about making up that section.

It had stopped raining in the night. The road to Clingman's Dome is still closed. We had to change motels because the Econolodge and many of the motels were booked due to a car show in Pigeon Forge. After breakfast we walked across the street to the Gillette Motel and we're in a our new room by 10:00. This is a family owned motel, older but nice. We had to pay $89.00 but this was the weekend rate I'm sure.
Noel, a hiker from Australia that I hiked with last year arrived in town overnight, so 2nd Dinner and I met him for a late lunch. We met at the outfitter's. And went to Blaine's to eat. Good food. Lots of hikers in town.
The sun was out but still cool out. The road to Clingman's Dome is still closed. All 3 of us will head back out in the morning. I'm skipping the 7 miles from Clingman's Dome to Newfound Gap. I'll do those in the fall. Went back to the room and packed and showered and relaxed. There will be lots of hikers going back in the morning so will see lots of people. Hope the road to Clingman's Dome is back open so the thruhikers can continue on and not have to worry about making up that section.

Headed out of Gatlinburg and hit the trail at 10:20. Noel and I are hiking together. Slick trail. Icy and snowy (anywhere from 2 - 8 inches). Arrived at the shelter at 1:30. The sun was bright and started to melt the snow. Now it's a slushy mess. It's 7:00 and am already in bed because it's getting colder. Think it's supposed to get down around 32 tonight. This will put the new quilt to the test.

Had an ok night but got chilly. Had to get up twice for nature calls which is bad enough but the path was slick and icy.Not something you want to deal with in the middle of the night.Left the shelter at 9:00 and stopped at Charlie's Bunion. It's an outcropping with beautiful views.   We had lots of beautiful scenery today. The sun was out all day but we still had to contend with ice and snow. I fell twice -- once due to ice and the other due to rocks and I'm not sure what else. Couldn't get up the first time because of all the ice and had to take my pack off and scoot until I could get some traction.Noel is having a tough time. His body is having to adjust to too many changes all at the same time -- time change, altitude, and hard hiking. We'll take it easy tomorrow, only 4.8 miles.Shelter is full again tonight...14 in one made for 12. Last night there were 19 in one made for 12.

Got cold and couldn't figure out why last night. Finally realized I didn't have the straps right on my quilt. So after I reworked those...was warm immediately. Today was a short day. Only had to hike 4.8 miles plus the additional .5 mile from the shelter to the trail. It was a beautiful sunny day and we just took our time and stopped many times. The snow is melting so we only have several yards of trail at a time that was snow covered today. Lots of mud, slush and water on the trail. We arrived at the shelter around 3:00. Views were great again today. Shelter is packed tonight -- 19 in a shelter for 12...And many tents. Hopefully the temps will be warmer tonight.

Nice night last night... Didn't have to get up once Stayed plenty warm too.Was up early and on the trail by 8:30. Easy day...Views were spectacular and temps were probably upper 60s. This part of the Smokies is mostly occupied by hikers. Very peaceful and serene. Starting to see wildflowers blooming. Shelter is packed again tonight. Something I didn't mention earlier because I didn't have all the facts. Last week a hiker was airlifted out due to hyperthermia. It was during the snow storm and she was a strong hiker but just got too cold. She had left the shelter to hike but came back a few minutes later and passed out after she sat down. Took the hikers in the shelter with her a little while to convince the rangers to send the helicopter.Another bad situation happened a couple of days ago. A father was hiking with his son and broke his ankle but made it to the shelter but couldn't walk so the rangers did a horse rescue. A wrangler and a ranger brought 3 horses to the shelter and they took the father out...Was a 12 mile ride out. His son had to walk out. I just missed seeing the horses by a couple of minutes. Noel (who is now called Grampa) showed me pictures.

Rained last night around 2:00 am. I had just gotten back in the shelter when it started. Only rained 15 mins or so and most things were dry by morning. Saw my first sunrise on the trail. It was great! We were on the trail by 8:15. We had a lot of miles to cover today.Hiking this morning was really pretty. We were headed down about 4,000ft. in elevation. Many more wildflowers blooming and things are much greener and drier. This afternoon we exited the Smokies. I've enjoyed the last 3 days of the park... beautiful scenery and great hiking once we got out of the snow and ice.Hiked by myself most of today. Grampa now hikes faster than I do so he went ahead to make sure we got beds at the hostel. This is our first double digit day. The first part of the day wasn't too hard but once we left the park it was hot and we had a little trouble finding the hostel. I got here at 3:30 and Grampa had already gotten us beds in cabin for 4 instead of the bunk room for 16. We've got more room and much less commotion. Glad he got here early. I picked up my dropbox and we had DiGourno pizza for dinner. They have everything a hiker needs here.   They have a store that runs on the honor system, showers, laundry (washboard and a regular dryer) and a kitchen.Sort of organized chaos with so many hikers here. We're in one of the hiker bubbles, meaning a large group of hikers that started at the same time. Think it will spread out a little since we're out of the park and don't have to stay in shelters anymore.

Got a late start at 9:30 this morning. New news--a mouse chewed thru the zipper on my backpack waist pocket. I should have unzipped it last night but since I was in a cabin didn't think about. Made it all the way thru the Smokies with no problems but the very next night it happened. At least I didn't encounter the mouse!!It was a long hard climb today...The worst yet. I had to keep stopping to catch my breath and the grade on the trail was really steep. Took us over 4 hours to hit the top of Snowbird Mtn. It had a grassy Bald on top and we ate lunch at the top. Also first time we've had good cell service in days. Got to the shelter around 4:30. Decided to sleep in the shelter because it will be easier to get going in the morning. Only 5 hikers in the shelter tonight.   Didn't cook tonight since I ate lunch around 2:30. Tired so hopefully will sleep well.

Started out at 8:45. Went up and down all morning. It was tough! Took wildflower pictures to distract myself. We summited Max Patch at 2:00.That is a summit cleared for cattle and it is maintained as a bald.   Views were spectacular! We spent an hour enjoying the view and eating lunch.  After we came off the bald, the terrain totally changed. Lots of rhodadendran bushes and almost a tropical feel. Took us about an hour to get to the shelter. Quite a few tents but only 4 of us in the shelter

Mm 255.5 to 265.0Started at 8:15 and had a very pleasant and easy hike this morning...many streams and footbridges and still that tropical feel. Many wildflowers all day and several new varieties. At Lemon Gap the First Baptist Church in Sevierville had left trail magic...brownies and cold soda. Tasted so good. Stopped at Walnut Mtn. Shelter for a little lunch. We weren't very hungry after the trail magic. Then we had a climb but it didn't seem too bad. When we got to the summit of Bluff Mtn. there was cell service so I made a couple of calls then hit the trail for a 1900 ft. descent. That was tough but we made it to the Old Road where we're stealth camping tonight. There are about 7 tents set up here. The plan is to hike into Hot Springs tomorrow and hopefully arrive early afternoon. Was hoping to attend Easter services but we won't have enough time to get to town and get cleaned up (and believe me we need a shower before we could set foot in a church). So we'll just get as many chores done tomorrow and then finish on Monday then hit the trail again on Tuesday heading for Erwin, TN.

Was so great sleeping in my tent last night. Nice to have some privacy. Got up early and saw the sunrise. Was on the trail by 7:30 -- pretty good since I had to pack up my tent. Hot Springs was 7.5 miles but it was a long 7.5 miles. The trail went up and down constantly but we arrived at noon. Checked out Laughing Heart Hostel and decided to stay there.   I'm in a room for 3 and there are real beds and sheets. The trail goes right thru town so we checked it out. Nice little town and most things a hiker needs within walking distance. My favorite is the Hillbilly Market. They have all kinds of sandwiches and great milkshakes which I intend to sample tomorrow.The hostel is providing Easter dinner at 4pm so we head back. Great food -- ham, mac & cheese, cream corn, green beans, salad, rolls and several kinds of dessert. Everyone enjoyed it immensely. After all that food we walked back to town and ended up sitting in rocking chairs on the porch of the Smoky Mtn. Diner. Good thing we made it there because it started raining and we would have gotten drenched. Rained for 20 minutes or so then it cleared off and the sun came back out. Walked back to the hostel and just relaxed. We're taking a zero tomorrow to rest and do chores in town. I'm having trouble getting a signal so I didn't get to call home and wish everyone a Happy Easter. Bummer!

Zero day in Hot Springs


Didn't sleep much last night.  The air conditioner in the room at the hostel was very noisy and I only got 4 hours sleep.  Went to the Smoky Mtn. Diner for breakfast.  Good food.  Found out that the hostel was booked for tonight so moved to the Alpine Court Motel in town.  Visited the Ridgeback Ministries...They just provide a place for hikers to relax and provide snacks.  Elizabeth who was hosting today was very nice and she is interested in eventually hiking the AT in sections.  We talked a few minutes and then I left to do more chores to get ready to resume hiking tomorrow.  It's been a struggle getting WiFi in this area.  We're in a valley surrounded by mountains so signals are hard to get.  Never could make a call.
Good news...I sent 3 lbs. of unneeded clothes and equipment to my sister's today.  Hope I don't need any of that stuff.  It will be good to have less weight on my pack. 
Had a nice dinner tonight and just relaxed.  Rain is forecast for the next 4 days...what fun.

Zero Day
  
Was sick (stomach issues) last night so I knew I couldn't hike today.  Went to pay for another night at the office and a different guy was there.  He charged me $101 instead of the $75 I paid last nite.  He said the other guy gave me last year's rate.  I was shocked but he walked away and made it clear he didn't want to discuss it anymore.  This is at the Alpine Court Motel in Hot Springs.   $ was a lot for this room but $101 was outrageous.  Just wanted to go back to bed so I didn't pursue it.  I found out that was what the guys next door paid.  It irritates me when hikers are taken advantage of.
Went to the library and bought a new book.  Rested all afternoon then took a short walk thru town.  Had a sandwich at the Smoky Mtn. Dinner.  Feeling much better.  Got things ready to leave in the morning.

Left at 8:30 this morning in the rain.  It was an uphill climb as usual out of town.  Rained until 10:30.  Trail levelled out some in the middle of the day.  Walked thru lots of burned areas.  Then 3.5 miles before the shelter we started climbing again.  Lots of up and down.  I was exhausted when I got to the shelter.  The last 1.5 miles all I could do was put one foot in front of the other.  Got to the shelter at 4:45--what a long day.

Didn't sleep well last night.  Spring Mtn. Shelter is small and old.  It only sleeps 5 and that's how many of us there were.  We got rain and the shelter roof leaked.  Thank goodness my quilt wasn't too wet.  There was a lot of noise and I heard the scampering of mice.  Tonight I'm sleeping in my tent.
Today seemed hard even tho we didn't have any huge ups or downs.  I fell due to slick mud.  Just another hard sit down.  There was a bright spot...We ran across a small convenience store just 100 yards off the trail.  It was too early for lunch but I got a soda and a Klondike Bar.  Both really hit the spot.
Finally got to the shelter around 4:00 and set up my tent.   Dried out my quilt and a few other things.  It's supposed to rain tonight but we dodged it all day and 2 dark rain clouds passed over in the first couple of hours I was here.  Hope my luck holds out.
Just a note...The privies since we left the Smoky Mtn. NP are awful.  They are really small, for example if they have a door it hits your knees when you sit down.  The one at this shelter doesn't have a door so it's not a problem, but the sides aren't tall enough so you don't know if you're giving everyone a show when you stand up.  Who built these things??
There was a bear here a couple nights ago.  He just rattled the bear cables then left when he couldn't get any of the food bags down.  Hope he doesn't visit tonight.  A couple of hikers have dogs so I wouldn't think he'd come near.  We'll see.

Got out in good time, 8:30.  Had an 1100' ascent then the trail levelled out a bit.  Went up to Big Firescald Knob.  We had a choice to take the regular AT or take a bypass trail which is the old AT.  The old AT section is easier but it was a sunny day and we felt good so we took the rockier one.  At the top you could see for miles and it was worth the climb.  The terrain reminded me of the hiking my sister and I did in NH.  Everything was going well when I slipped and fell sideways.  I yelled and Grandpa Perth ran back.  I couldn't get up because my pack had my arm pinned.  I unbuckled my pack and Grandpa pulled me up enough to release my arm.  Surprisingly I escaped with only some scratches and aches.  Bet I'll be sore tomorrow.
Started raining about half a mile before the shelter.  We had planned to get water then move on but we decided to stay in the shelter.  I'd rather be in my tent but didn't want to put it up in the rain.  We have 8 in a shelter for 6...Really crammed in.  Bet I won't get much sleep tonight.  At least the rain has stopped.

Rained for several hours last night with some thunder and lightning.  It was dry and warm in the shelter.  I slept fairly well last night...probably one of the best nights in a shelter.  Started hiking at 7:50 spurred on by the thoughts of real food and a shower.
The trail was fairly easy today.  Got to Flint Mtn. Shelter before noon and had lunch.  We were ready to leave and it started raining so put on rain gear and pack cover.  Glad it started before we started hiking again so we wouldn't have to stop and pull out the rain gear.  Walked for an hr  and a half and came to Devil Fork Gap.  There were 2 cars there so I figured we might be able to get a ride.  We didn't know where the hostel was.  One of the cars belonged to Bunje's wife, Sherry.  We had met Bunje yesterday and had seen him a couple of times this morning.  Sherry offered to take us wherever we wanted to go.  She was staying at Hemlock Hollow Hostel and told us it was nice, so she took us there.  She's providing support for her husband on his hike.
Sherry was right this is a great hostel.  The bunk room holds 10 and we have 9 here.  The rain brought everyone in.  We had pizza for dinner and it tasted so good.  It had stopped raining for 4 hrs., but started raining around 6pm and hasn't stopped since.  The forecast is for 100 percent chance of rain most of the day tomorrow.  Looks like we may stay another day.  The trail was already muddy and slick today...it will be worse tomorrow.
Destination: Devil Fork Gap ( Hemlock Hollow Hostel)

Journal Story:
It rained all last night and all day until about 6:00pm.  I estimate they got 2-3 inches in 24 hrs.  Grandpa Perth and I went to church this morning at the church about 1/4 mile from the hostel.  It was different from the churches either of us attend but we were glad we went.
Since it rained all day the hostel was full and hikers even pitched tents in a farm building that was open on all sides but had a roof.  We just relaxed and talked with other hikers the rest of the day.
The hostel has grocery items hikers can use for resupply and also a kitchen so we could prepare food to eat while staying there.  I had a frozen chicken pot pie for dinner -- it tasted good!
One of the couples hiking is from Venezuela.  They told us about the issues in their country since their government has changed.  Made us all glad we live in America.  Went to bed around ten and slept well.
Start location: Devil Fork Gap ( Hemlock Hollow Hostel)

Journal Story:
Mon., 4/24
Hemlock Hollow Hostel (Devil Fork Gap) to Hogback Ridge Shelter
6.3 miles
With all the hikers leaving the hostel today, shuttles back to the trail were at a premium.  Ours was scheduled to leave at 10am, but this morning we were told we could leave at 8:30 if we wanted which we definitely did.  So we were back on the trail at 9:15.  Walked .5 mile and checked out Little Laurel Hostel (where we had originally planned to stay last Saturday).  It is smaller and not as many amenities, but still better than sleeping in your tent.
Started the climb up 1500' toward the shelter.  It was not as muddy and slick as I expected.  There were beautiful waterfalls due to all the rain.  Got to the shelter at 2:15 but the next one is 10 miles further so we stopped here.  The shelter only had room left for one so I'm tenting tonight.  It has rained a little this evening so I hope it stops so my tent will dry out before I have to pack it up in the morning.

My tent was wet when I woke up this morning.  It had rained last night and when it wasn't raining the trees were dripping on my tent.  The tent didn't leak, thank goodness, but everything outside the tent was wet.  Packed up and was hiking by 8:30.
We climbed up all day long and the trail was covered with wet, slick mud.  We were socked in with fog until noon then the sun was out for a few minutes.  The higher we climbed the more the fog rolled back in.  Our last mountain to climb was Bald Mountain then once we summited the trail seemed to go in circles forever.  I don't know what the purpose of that was.  When we got to the top 2nd Dinner arrived and said this was her worst day ever.  She's young and strong and several other strong hikers said the same thing.  I know I was beat and could hardly do all my evening chores in addition to trying to dry out my tent.  Finally put it up wet then the sun came out for a few minutes and dried it a little. The shelter only had spots available in the loft and there are no ladders.  I probably would kill myself trying to get up in the middle of the night.
Walked by the shelter around 7:30 and everyone was already in bed...unusual for this group so I guess they're tired too.  What a day!

I woke up in the middle of the night to find a heavy dew and the fly entrance soaked as badly as when it had gotten wet in the rain.  I had put my tent fly up wet because there wasn't any sun to dry it yesterday.   In the morning it had dried overnight and the dew was gone also.  Was hiking by 8:15.  Conditions had improved and after the first hour there wasn't nearly as much mud.
We reached the road at Spivey Gap a little before 1:00.  We thought we'd hitch into Erwin but in almost an hour only bicycles and motorcycles passed by so we started walking.  It was over 80 degrees and the sun was hot.  Had no cell service to call a shuttle.  Walked a mile and came to a few houses.  I decided to knock on one of them and ask if they would call a shuttle.  First house...no answer.  I was walking up to a mobile home when a guy on a ATV came across a field and waved.  I explained what I wanted and he said he could do better than that.  He'd take us to town and that's what happened.  He took us to the Uncle Johnny's Hostel where I got my drop box, took us on a tour of town and finally dropped us at the Super 8 where we had reservations.  Thank you Tommy!!!  He also told us that his mother had Grandma Gatewood (first woman to thru hike the AT) as a house guest on each of her 3 thru hikes and they had become friends.  How cool!!!
Checked in, showered and did laundry then went to a Mexican restaurant (Azteca) for dinner.  Very good food.  It was at least a mile there and a mile back.  I had on my camp shoes.  Should have worn my hiking boots.  My feet are aching now.  We zero tomorrow so they'll have a chance to rest.

Got a shuttle to Walmart this morning for a few supplies.  Back at the motel by 11:45 and spent the afternoon repacking and relaxing.  Went to Hawg & Dawg (BBQ) for dinner. Good BBQ.
Shuttle is scheduled for 8:15 in the morning to go.back to Spivey Gap to do the section from there into Erwin.  We plan to slackpack this section which means we will carry a day pack with a few supplies rather than our full packs.  We have 11.1 miles to do tomorrow.

Our shuttle driver picked us up at 8:15 and took us to Uncle Johnny's Hostel so we could drop our packs and pick up day packs.  We are slackpacking today.  The driver then took us up to Spivey Gap then we'll hike back to Uncle Johnny's.  He told us the reason there weren't cars on the stretch of road where we tried to hitch a couple of nights ago was because that road doesn't go anywhere.  It is just used by those who live in that gap.  
We started hiking at 8:45.  It was a steep climb  but with just a day pack it wasn't bad.  It felt like we could fly up and down the trail.  The morning was cool and sunny so it was a great hike.  But around noon it heated up and topped out in the mid 80's.  It was hot but I finished the 11 miles by 2:30.  This is hiker fest weekend here and all the hostel is booked so we're tenting.  There are tents everywhere, about 70 hikers are here tonight.  The hostel made a Cajun Boil with shrimp, sausage, boiled potatoes, and corn on the cob.  It was delicious.
Before dinner we rode bikes to the Citgo convenience store.  The hostel has about 20 old bikes that hikers can just take out for a ride.  Nice to be on 2 wheels instead of 2 feet.
Tomorrow morning we're going to send a box of food forward to another hostel where we'll be in about a week.  My dropbox that I picked up was for 5-6 days and we can resupply in 3 days and make our packs much lighter.  Should be helpful to do that...we'll see.

Took the 8:30 shuttle into town for breakfast at McDonald's and then went to the post office at 10:00 when it opened.  I sent 4 lbs. of food ahead to Mountain Harbour Hostel.  We'll be there in about 6 days.  By the time we got back to the hostel it was 11:00 and the temps were already climbing into the 80s headed for 90.  We were unmotivated and decided to zero today.
The hostel is packed again today.  A church from Jonesborough, TN had a cookout for hikers at lunchtime.  The food was wonderful!  Later this afternoon we went across the street to soak our feet in the Nolichucky River... felt so refreshing.  There was a snake in the water but he didn't raise his head above the surface of the water until after we took our feet out.  We couldn't tell how big he was but I'm glad we didn't know he was there while our feet were in the river.
Tonight the hostel served huge baked potatoes topped with chili, cheese and sour cream... yum.  I'll have to waddle to the trail tomorrow morning.  After dinner there was a talent show and  now I'm ready for bed.  It's still warm but I hope it cools down and doesn't rain.  It was a good day!

Got up early and hit the trail by 8:00.  There was a lot of noise until about midnight so didn't get a full night's sleep.  The walk was a gradual, steady ascent.  We had planned to camp at Indian Grave Gap but there really wasn't any good place to camp.  We arrived there around 2:00 and ate lunch.  We had finished eating and Noel (who is now called No Worries) said he wished he had an ice cold soda and we joked that maybe the car across the road had one in his trunk.  A second later a green van pulled up and the driver asked us if we wanted a cold soft drink.  We couldn't believe it...Then Second Dinner jumped out of the van.  The  driver was Miss Janet, a famous trail angel that everyone talks about and writes about in their journals.  She was dropping off slackpackers.  She gave us a cold soda and told us to leave the cans on the steps and she'd come back for them.  Unbelievable!!!!
After our trail magic, we started up the mountain looking for someplace to camp.  We've ended up in a power line clearing with a beautiful view but very gusty wind.  I had a terrible time pitching my tent.  No Worries had to help me.  I'm not sure I will be able to keep my stove lit to boil water.  Might be a PB&J nite.

What a horrible night last night.  The wind howled all night.  It bombarded my tent all nite.  It would  come from one direction then a second later come from the other.  The forecast was for gusts of 36mph but it seemed stronger.  The tent held up well but I wasn't sure it would hold.  I got less than 3 hrs. of sleep.  Woke up at 3am and started packing up the stuff inside the tent then at 5am woke up No Worries and told him I wanted to take down the tents before it started to rain...if it rained with all that wind everything would get soaked.  So we did that in the dark.  We walked up the trail about 50 ft. and there was enough forest to protect us from the wind.  We laid down on the side of the trail and rested until it was light.  Ate a few bites of breakfast and started hiking at 7am.
It was slow going because we were both so tired.  Climbed up to Beauty Spot which is a bald mountain.  Several hikers spent the night there with the same problems we had.  Started raining at 9am and rained until we got to the shelter at 2:00.  Everyone was wet but some were pushing on to the hostel or the next shelter.  We stayed put.  Took a 2 hr. nap and felt much better.  When I woke up the sun was out and the rain had stopped.  We're in a small shelter for 6 and that's how many are in it.  Hung up all our wet things and they are drying out.  It's almost 8:00 and I think I'll get ready for bed.  I'm still tired.

Tues, 5/2
Cherry Gap Shelter to Greasy Creek Hostel
Mm 367.0, 7.2 miles
Had a good night's sleep.  Before I went to sleep last night there was a big gust of wind and the temp dropped immediately.  Must have been a front moving thru but I slept warm.  Up and on the trail by 8am.  Just a normal day of hiking up and down mountains.  We ran into Miss Janet at one of the road crossings.  She is so nice and willing to help.  She asked us twice if there was anything we needed.
The walk to the hostel was 0.6 mile which seemed to take forever.  We got here at 1:00 so we were happy with that.  We're at Greasy Creek Friendly.  We are sharing our room with a girl from Zurich.  She has just started her hike and will be hiking for a month.  You meet people from everywhere on the trail.  CeeCee and Mark run the hostel...What a lot of work...They deserve a lot of credit.  We ordered dinner from Mountain Grill and went into town to pick it up and made a stop at the convenience store for resupply.  Will sleep on a real mattress tonight!!

We slackpacked today.  Erica, our shuttle driver, took us from the hostel north to Carver's Gap and then we hiked back to the hostel.  It was a beautiful day and great views.  Started at 9:45 and made it back to the hostel at 5:00.  It took us longer to do this section because the trail was so busy.  We met lots of hikers from Uncle Johnny's that we hadn't seen in a few days.  So we had to stop and chat with everyone.
It was fun slackpacking and we'll try to do it often.  You feel so free with just a daypack.  It's like a vacation.  We actually hiked 12.5 miles today because the hostel is 0.6 mile off the trail.
Pizza for dinner and a nice shower and a good bed.  It was a great day!!

Erica took us back to Carver's Gap and we started hiking at 8:45.  The wind was blowing and we were worried about rain.  There were differing reports about when it would start.  Our first 0.7 mile was a gentle ascent but the issue was the wind.  It was blowing at least 80 mph.  It blew me over twice.  The first time I couldn't move forward and I stuck my poles in the dirt and it still blew me over.  No Worries was a little was a little ways ahead of me and he had turned around to see how I was doing and he said he saw my feet fly up in the air.  After I hit the ground I tried to figure out how to get up.  I knew the wind would just blow me over again even if I could get up.  So I unbuckled me pack and about that time I heard No Worries say get up and give me your pack.  Was I ever glad to see him.  Even he had trouble staying upright as he carried mine back to where he'd left his pack.
The second blowdown just blew me to my knees which was't so bad.  There were several times where the wind would blow you off the trail but still leave you on your fe
The wind blew the entire time we hiked today but once we got over the bald there was enough tree and bush cover that the wind didn't blow us over anymore.  We booked to Overmountain Shelter and there were about 10 hikers already here.  We arrived at 12:15...Too early to stop but with rain coming in we're staying.  Don't know how rainproof this old drafty barn is but it will hold probably 30 hikers and we have a roof over our heads.

Well last night was good and bad.  It rained steadily until sometime between midnight and 4am.  Everyone got at least damp to some who got wet due to the rain blowing into the loft. I had put my tent fly over my quilt so I only got damp.  No Worries' sleeping bag was soaked at the bottom.  A lot of that was due to condensation.
We started hiking at 8:30 and had a big climb up Little Hump Mtn.  Then we descended a bit and climbed up Hump Mtn.  The guide says it is only a 700' climb but I know it's more than that.  There are at least 3 false summits which is very discouraging...you think you're the top but you're not.  By the time we got to the top of Hump Mtn. the clouds and fog had moved in and we couldn't see anything.  Disappointing.
By noon we were at Doll Flats where we cross over into TN and leave NC for the last time.  We've been straddling the NC/TN border for many days now.  Glad to say goodbye to NC.  I will say the views we had today before summiting Big Hump are more scenic than even the Smokies.
The sun came out when we got to the base of Hump and we ate lunch in the warm sunshine.  It started  raining by 1:00 and we made it to the road by 2:30 and walked to Mountain Harbour Hostel where I needed to pick up the box I had forwarded from Erwin.  We had tent sites reserved because the hostel was full.  We really needed to dry out our wet gear so I called Doe Rest Hostel and we got the last 2 beds.  Dave came and picked us up from the top of Mtn. Harbour and took us to our home for the evening.  They had 2 pickup trucks running  shuttles tonight but both were going to a Thai restaurant and we wanted a different kind of food so they gave us a car to take into town... unbelievablely nice.  So I drove No Worries and Quiet Man to the Dairy Bar and had grilled chicken dinner.   Pogo and Sweet Tea are staying here also along with other hikers we run into frequently.
The forecast for tomorrow is 90% chance of rain and temps in the 30s tomorrow night so we're staying another day.  Wish this rain would stop!!!

Sat, 5/6
Zero day in Roan Mtn. TN
0.0
The shuttle service at Doe's Rest Hostel is great.   All shuttles into town and to and from the trail are free for guests.  So we went into town for breakfast at the Smoky Mtn. Bakery.  Great food.  Very small place but has lots of business.  Then we walked to the RediMart and the convenience store at the Valero station.  When we finished we called the hostel and Shaggy came and picked us up and took us back to the hostel.
I did laundry and then we rode back into town to the Hiker Fest with Dave the hostel owner.  It was cold and rainy and even the free hot chocolate and homemade baked goods couldn't keep us warm.  Dave ran some errands and then came back to pick us up in an hour.  We were really glad to see him and his warm truck.  Too bad the weather was so bad...a  lot of people worked hard to put the hiker fest  together and it was too cold and rainy for anyone to attend.   Went to the hostel and got in bed to warm up.  Rested for an hour and found out that the hostel was completely full.  There were hikers everywhere.  The family of 7 that is hiking is staying in a trailer on Dave's property.
Went back to the Smoky Mtn. Bakery for a light dinner.  I just had salad but it was good.  Packed up and got ready to head back to the trail in the morning.  Hope the weather clears.

We were on the trail by 9:15 this morning.  The sun was shining and it was 45 degrees.   It warmed up quickly to a comfortable hiking temp.  It was a perfect day for hiking.  (On the ride to the trail we saw snow on the mountain tops...glad  we weren't up there.)  The trail today was fairly easy, thus being able to do 12.7 miles.   We went thru all kinds of terrain.  It is only .1 off the trail to Jones Falls so we went there for lunch.  Beautiful waterfalls
We walked thru meadows on mountain tops,  Laurel Falls and just rolling hills.  We arrived at Laurel Fork at 3:45.  Since we took a 1/2 hr. for lunch that means we did 12.7 miles in  7 hours.  Not bad for us old folks.  We're camped ri!ght beside the creek tonight.  Might get down in the 30's tonight but no rain is forecast. 
We ate dinner with Tequila Sunshine and Happy Feet.  It has been the best day yet on the trail.

Mon, 5/8
Laurel Fork to Dennis Cove Rd. (Black Bear Resort)
12.0 miles
Got cold last night and I had to put on my baselayer and my down jacket, then I was cozy.  There was a heavy dew so my tent fly was wet.  
I had thought today would be like yesterday but it was more difficult.  We had lunch at Moreland Gap Shelter.  I was so cold when we left there.  The wind was blowing right into the front of the shelter and even with a jacket on I was freezing.
We decided to slackpack tomorrow so we walked the 0.4 mile to Black Bear Hostel.  It is a beautiful place.  We initially signed up to tent, but the wind was really strong and rain was supposed to move in late afternoon so we got a cabin with another hiker.  Splitting it 3 ways made it as cheap as a bed in the bunkroom.  The bathrooms and shower were so clean and the grounds are immaculate.

I thought I was going to die today!!!  We slackpacked southbound from US321 back to Dennis Cove Rd.  We were concerned about the almost 2,000 ft. ascent and descent over Pond Mountain.  Well, that was a piece of cake.  No issues and we did those miles in good time.  Then we ate lunch and started toward Laurel Falls.  When we were almost there things got dicey.  With the rain last night and this morning the rocks and roots were very slippery.  The river was high and running very fast.  We thought the trail went up several feet from the river so we tried going up that way and ran into a dead end.  I had to sit down and scoot in order to make it back down to where we left the trail.  When we found where the trail went there was nothing to grab onto to get around a large rock which was inches from the water.  I was petrified...if I slipped and fell in the water I would drown.  So I sat down again and inched across the rock.  Thank goodness No Worries was with me or I don't know how I would have made it.  Then we made it to Laurel Falls which were beautiful but I'm not sure it was worth the trauma to get there.  There are 100 rock steps to get back to the top of the rigde.  Those were slick also, but going up isn't a problem.  So that small section of trail to and from the falls took us about 1.5 hrs.
We finally made it back to our cabin at 3:30.  What a day!!!

We were sad to leave Black Bear Resort.  Bob, our shuttle driver, took us back to where we started yesterday and we started north again.  Walked around Watauga Lake...it was beautiful.  The AT in this area has a history of bear problems so they ask that you don't camp in this area.  As far as we know there have been no bear sightings this year here.  We took pictures but waited to eat lunch until we had hiked thru the area.
It was just up and down all afternoon.  No big elevation changes just PUDS (pointless ups and downs).  Made it to the shelter by 3:30 and we were the only ones here.  By 8:30 the place is packed.  Tequila Sunshine, Happy Feet, Darwin, Sherlock, Neopolitan, and Marco all are here along with the Family of 7 (minus the mother who has a hurt ankle) and many others.  We have tents pitched on the actual trail.  It was a tiring day and I'm ready to sleep.

I was sure I'd heard rain last night on my tent but it was dry and no one else had heard it rain.  I was pleasantly surprised when I opened my tent fly this morning.  We got an early start at 7:45.
The terrain was much the same as yesterday...lots of PUDs.  We had some good views of the Watauga Valley.  Ate lunch at Iron Mtn. Shelter.
We came out at TN 91 and just before we got there No Worries said he wanted an ice cold soda...I laughed and said fat chance of that happening.  He got to the road before I did and was talking to a woman in a car when I arrived.  I heard her ask him if he needed a ride somewhere and before I knew what had happened we were in her car and she was offering us a room for the night.  After  a little more discussion we found out she runs Iron Mtn. Inn and she had a room available for the night.  It was $100 and a little too steep for us.  She did take us to the restaurant 4 miles down the road so we got cold soda after all and then she brought us back to the trail.  Thanks Vicki!
The next part of the trail was thru pasture land... very pretty.  We pitched our tents in a wooded area next to a pasture full of cows.  We ate dinner and then I noticed the cows moving from one pasture to the other and a little brown calf stayed in the pasture all by himself.  A huge mother cow came up over the hill but ignored the calf and went in the second pasture with all the other cows.  I stood and watched all this and then the mother cow went back to the first pasture and up over the hill still ignoring the little calf.  She was concerned about something down the other side of the hill so I decided to find out what.   I crossed the ladder over the fence and walked cautiously toward the cow being careful not to get between the cow and calf.  As I walked over the top of the hill I didn't see anything.  Then I saw what looked like a rock move.  I walked closer keeping my eye on the cow.  It was another calf and as I talked softly to it, it struggled to stand up and finally did.  It walked toward mom and I moved the other direction.  I was so happy when the calf started nursing.  All the other cows had moved to the gate and were watching.  I had to walk in front of all of them so I just moved slowly and talked softly until I got over the fence.  A couple of hours later I heard one cow very upset but it was too dark to see what the problem was.  There are no houses close around here so I don't know who these cows belong to.
We had a brief rain shower before I went to sleep, hope that's all the rain we get tonight.
Destination: past TN 91( north end of handicapped trail)

Journal Story:
It rained most of the night last night and was still raining when we packed up this morning.  We left at 7:45.  It rained for about an hour and then stopped.  In order to get to Damascus today we would have to hike more than 20 miles and all our gear was wet so we didn't want to set up camp tonight, so we only did 5.7 and got off at Low Gap.
 We walked to Shady Valley which was 2.7 miles and had lunch at the only restaurant in town.  The cheeseburger and fries were delicious.  Then we went across the road to the country store.  Both the clerk and another man said we'd be able to get a ride to Damascus if we just waited for someone to come into the store.  So we waited about an hour and only 4-5 people came in and none were going to Damascus, but they insisted we'd get a ride. Another half hour passed and still no ride.  Then the tornado warnings came on our phones.  The storm came in very quickly.  We could see the clouds rolling on top of the mountain we'd hiked over this morning.  No Worries looked out the window and saw someone's roof flying across the field.  The clerk was scared and on the phone to her boss who told her to go to the basement.  She said she had an "old couple" in the store with her and her boss said to take them with her.  The electricity had gone out a few minutes before and there were 3 others in the store with us.  We found out that these people were going to Damascus and they graciously agreed to give us a ride so we were on our way.  Thank you Bill and brother-in-law and daughter-in-law.
It rained the whole way there.  They took us to the Methodist Church which runs a hostel which luckily had a few beds available.  No one else in town did.  We showered and had Mexican food for dinner.  It's almost 10pm and lights out.
Start location: past TN 91( north end of handicapped trail)

Journal Story:
Sat, 5/13
Low Gap to Damascus
15.2 miles
Our shuttle driver, Jeff from Mt. Rogers Outfitters, took us back to Low Gap where we got off the trail yesterday.  There were no available shuttles at the outfitters so he came in early to take us back...Thanks Jeff!  We started hiking at 7:50.
It was a long day slackpacking but after the first 4.5 miles the trail was either downhill or relatively flat with the usual ups and downs but no big climbs.  We were in the fog until about 1:00 then it started to clear up.  By the time we got into Damascus it was sunny and warm.  It was before 3:30.
We put all our wet gear out to dry and No Worries returned the day packs the outfitters loaned us.  A few minutes later one of the guys that works at the outfitters came to the hostel.  He had found my phone in the day pack and I hadn't even missed it yet.  That's what I call service!
We went to Bo Bo's for dinner.  Good food and lots of hikers there.  We checked out some of the other hostels because there is a 2 night limit at The Place.  Couldn't decide what to do but we decided late tonight to move to Montgomery Homestead tomorrow morning.  It's an 1920s Arts & Crafts style house with 4 bedrooms to rent out.

I called the owner of the Montgomery Homestead at 7:30am.  Susie said she still had rooms available.  Then I told her we had another problem...The Place doesn't have laundry so we hadn't had a chance to do laundry and we wanted to go to the 11:00 church service.  She said she'd do our laundry if we could get it to her in the next few minutes.  She lives right across from The Place so I told her we'd be there in 5 minutes.  Ninety minutes later our clothes were done and she had cleaned the rooms so we could move right in.  Thank you so much Susie!!!
We went to The First Baptist Church and were impressed with how friendly the people were and we enjoyed the service.  Ribbons came with us to church and she needed a ride to be pick up a rental car tomorrow.  Before she left the church she had a ride to pick up the car as well as a place to stay at Susie's as well as help with getting set up with a Dr. to check out her leg.  Wonderful people!
We had lunch and ice cream with Tequila Sunshine and Happy Feet.  She is flying home tomorrow and Happy Feet is continuing on the trail.  That was the plan when they started but we'll miss her.
The rest of the day we shopped, repacked, relaxed, etc.  It was a beautiful, sunny day.  I really have enjoyed my stay at Montgomery Homestead and would like to stay another day, but the trail calls.

I didn't want to get up this morning or to leave Montgomery Homestead.  But I had to do both.  I went by Susie's and dropped off the room key.  I'm glad I got to say goodbye and thank her for all the help she gave us.  It's a little more expensive for a room ($75 which includes laundry) but definitely worth it.
We hit the trail by 8:50am.  We took the Virginia Creeper Trail which is the old AT because it's an old railroad bed and easier and more scenic.  We stopped to eat our lunch at Taylor's Valley.  The trail goes right beside the creek which is now a raging river due to all the rain.  It was a very scenic walk.
It warmed up this afternoon and we were actually too warm.  About 1:30 we sat down on a bench next to the trail and just closed our eyes.  A young hiker came along and we both looked up and the hiker looked concerned and asked if we were ok.  I guess we didn't look too good.  We were tired and our packs were heavy from resupply and we had already hiked over 10 miles.
We got to the shelter around 3:30 and I pitched my tent and No Worries is staying in the shelter.  There is a woman (Tweety) from Elwood, IN camped here tonight.  She did a thru hike several years ago and is on her way south to Damascus for Trail Days with a couple of other hikers.  She saw me pitching my tent and she just had a feeling I was from IN, but she thought I was the hiker the Indpls. Star did an article about.  So she was half right, I'm from IN but not the one the Star did a story about.
It's about 7:45 and I think I'm going to bed soon.  I'll try to hold out until it gets almost dark.

Up and on the trail by 8:00.  The first order of the day was a 2,000 ft. climb up Whitetop Mtn.  We had an early lunch on Buzzard Rock which has 360 degree views.  It was clear and sunny and we could see for miles.  Then we made it to the parking lot at Elk Garden around 2:00 and decided to go to Marion.  No Worries hasn't had cell service to call home for over 5 days and he needed to do that.  So we started to hitch and a southbound day hiker offered to take us to Damascus with him.  He was worried that if he left us at the Chilhowie exit at I-81 that we'd not be able to get a ride, so we went with him.  As soon as we got to town and had a cold drink, we went to Mt. Roger's Outfitters and Jeff, who had helped us out with a shuttle last Saturday, worked his magic again and found us a ride to Marion.
We checked into the Travel Inn which only charges $47 + tax for rooms.  We had Mexican food for dinner since that was the closest place.  Made phone calls, watched TV, showered, and went to bed.

Wed, 5/17
Zero Day in Marion, VA
0.0
Had a tough time getting to sleep last night.  Finally slept at 1:30 but the most sound sleep was from 6-8:00 this morning.  Went to Walmart and had a salad at McDonald's for lunch.  Bought a new shirt to sleep in and wear in town.  My current one is fleece lined and too warm.  Will send some more cold weather clothes home after I get thru Grayson Highlands tomorrow.
Relaxed this afternoon.

Rambunny shuttled us back to Elk Garden.  It was so great to see her.  We started hiking at 9:00.   Our first climb was up Mt. Rogers, about a 1,000 ft climb over 4 miles.  Not too bad.  Ate lunch at Thomas Knob Shelter.  We had great views all afternoon but the trail was rocky the whole time.  We saw and petted wild ponies before we even got to Grayson Highlands Park and then didn't see any more.  We saw another small group from the ridge but never saw them once we got closer to where we thought they were.
Got to Wise Shelter around 4 and I decided to stay in the shelter because it's supposed to rain tonight.  After dinner a mother pony and colt came by the shelter...Stopped to graze  a few minutes then moved on.  A few minutes later the dad came running by.  He's now grazing just past the shelter close to where hikers are camped.  The log book for this shelter says there's a raccoon who climbs up trees and gets food bags down.  Ours are hung in a tree so I hope we still have food in the morning.
Beautiful views today but we had to really concentrate on our feet to make sure we didn't stumble.  So it's almost 8:00 and I'm thinking about getting in my quilt.

What a night we had last night.  Everyone  was in bed in the shelter and it  was dead quiet.  Suddenly there  was a very loud swoosh and I had lost all the air in my sleeping  pad and was lying on the hard board floors  of the shelter.  The plug to the pad had come out.  I started laughing and No Worries asked "What happened?"   I got up snd blew it back up.  I think the strap to my pillow had wrapped around the plug and when I pulled on my pillow the plug came out.  What a shock and a lot of noise!
The rain had stopped late afternoon but at 2am I woke up for a nature call and the wind was blowing really hard.  As I got out of the shelter it was like a spigot had been turned on.  When I got back in bed, wet from being outside, everyone was grabbing stuff that was in danger of getting soaked.  When we all got back in our sleeping bags there was a huge clap of thunder.  Made everyone jump.  
Up and on the trail at  7:50 this morning..  It was a beautiful, sunny day.  Nothing of note on the trail but the rhodedendrons are starting to bloom.  They are gorgeous!  When I came out of the woods at Dickey Gap, No Worries was talking to a guy standing next to a pickup truck.  Evidently No Worries had walked a few yards to a main road and this guy, Casey, had stopped to see if he needed assistance.  So Casey had offered to take us up the road to Sugar Gap to the convenience store and then bring us back to the trail.  We jump in the bed of Casey's truck and have a great ride into town.  The sun is shining and the wind is blowing in our faces.  It rrminded me of when I used to ride mororcycles.  We get sandwiches, chips, soft drinks and I get an ice cream sandwich.  Thanks so much Casey!!!

We started out at 7:40 hikng toward Partnership Shelter.  Our plan was to get a ride from the Mt.Roger's Visitor Center into Marion for the night.  The hike was about normal but rocky.   I had just reached a smooth stretch of trail when I saw No Worries on his knees beside the trail facing away from me.  I hurried toward him and asked him if he was sick, then I saw his bloody face.  He had tripped on a small tree stump at the side of the trail.   I pulled out my first aid kit and wet wipes and cleaned his face.  He had 2 gashes on his forehead and several cuts on his nose.  I was worried that he would need stitches on his forehead.  He complained about his neck hurting and I thought he'd probably twisted it trying to keep his face from hitting the ground.  I put Band-Aids on his cuts and he said he was ready to go.  So we put on our packs and started walking.
In about 1/4 mile we came to a gravel road and decided we should try to get to town from there instead of hiking the last 4 miles to Partnership Shelter.  I still thought No Worries needed to go to a Medcheck to get his cuts cleaned and possibly get some stitches.  I pulled out my phone and realized I didn't know who to call.  I started with the Mt. Roger's Visitors Center hoping they could send a ranger or someone to take us to town.   They told me to call the sheriff's office and gave me the number.  I called and they asked me to call back in on 911 so they could get a ping from my phone.  I was fairly sure we were at VA 601 but they didn't know exactly where it crossed the AT.  Finally after I walked down the road several hundred yards they got a ping and said they would send rescue.  Didn't know what that meant but it was already in progress.
 After about 15 minutes and no one had come I started to call again when we heard noise at the trail crossing.  No Worries had walked down to where I was when I was on the phone earlier so no one was at the trail crossing to tell them where we were so I started running uphill to the noise.  I rounded the curve and saw an ambulance with red lights flashing.  I thought oh no, this is overkill.  No Worries thought the same thing.  The EMTs examined No Worries and after he complained about his neck, they put him in a collar.  They took us to Marion Hospital and after a Cat Scan the doctor told us that No Worries had fractured his C-1 and C-2 vertebrae in his neck.  We were both stunned.  After discussion the doctor arranged for us to go by ambulance to the Johnson City Medical Center since Marion Hospital isn't equipped to handle his injury.   It was an hour and 40 minute ride to Johnson City.  The neurosurgeon will talk to No Worries tomorrow to tell him whether surgery is needed.

Very tired from all the activity yesterday.  I learned how to navigate the bus system in Johnson City.  By the end of the day they had decided to do surgery on No Worries' neck tomorrow to put 2 screws in the C-2 vertebrae because they aren't sure it will heal properly on its own.

Got up early and took the bus to the laundromat.  What a bunch of stinky clothes!   Just as I was leaving the laundromat to go to the hospital it started raining.  The bus stop didn't have any cover so I stood across the street under the overhang at the gas station.  A very nice lady, Janet, asked me if I needed a ride and she took me to the hospital.  Another wonderful trail angel!!  No Worries had surgery to put a screw in his vertebrae.  All went well.

Back on the trail...hiked 4.6 miles to account for those that I missed when I helped No Worries.  Am hiking with Big Blue Tony for a few days.  He has a car and so we're slackpacking for a couple of days.
The hike today was very scenic...very green and not difficult.  Staying at Partnership Shelter tonight.  Around 5:00 we had a rain downpour but by dark the stars were out.  This shelter is very nice...has most of the amenities hikers want...a shower (cold water), a sink and water faucet so you don't need to filter water, a covered picnic table, a clean and non-smelling outhouse, a trash bin for garbage, and bathrooms at the Visitor's Center with flush toilets.  It's jjust the simple things in life that make us happy.  O yes, how could I forget, a phone outside the Visitor's Center that can be used to order pizza.

I was on the trail by 7:45 today.  Big Blue Tony took his car to Settler's Museum and hiked south while I hiked the same section north.  When I got to the museum I drove the car to Partnership Shelter where Tony ended his hike.  When I arrived at the Visitor's Center (.2 from the shelter) he wanted to go into Marion and get a motel, so that's what we did.  Found Jennifer and Gabe who had been in town for 12 days because of Jennifer's knee problem.  They're getting back on the trail doing 4-6 miles slackpacking until her knee is better.  Lots of injuries happening.  It was good to catch up with them.
We planned out the next 9 days until I leave for R.I. to meet up with my sister, Yvonne, to hike Maine together.  Tomorrow is a 12.5 mile slackpack day, so I need to get some sleep.  There were another couple of rain showers at 4:00 and 8:00pm.  When will the rain ever stop.  The trail is muddy.

(I am skipping the 2.8 mile section between the Settler's Museum and VA 683 because I did that several years ago when Brenda and I visited Rambunny and Aqua.)
I dropped Tony at the Settler's Museum and took the car to O'Lystery Pavilion where he will pick it up at the end of his day.  I slackpacked today but it was a tough day.  The trail was sloppy mud in many places and slick.  I managed to stay upright all day.  Started out foggy but it quickly burned off and we had a beautiful, sunny day and the forecast for the next 3 days is warm and sunny.  Should dry up the mud.  Started at 7:45 and finished around 4:00.  Saw a large deer.  She was crossing the trail slowly but when she saw me, she jumped to the other side of the trail and ran off.
Had planned to visit with Rambunny and Aqua today but it didn't work out so Big Blue Tony (BBT) picked me up and we had dinner at The Barn in Adkins.  Good food!  We're both tired so we're planning to sleep in the car rather than pitch our tents.  That will also allow us to get on the trail earlier tomorrow morning.  Planning to do 3 days with BBT hiking south and I'll hike north.  We will be back to carrying our full packs.

BBT left at 6:46am to take the car to Bland, VA.  He will then hike south and I'll hike north from O'Lystery Pavilion (VA 42).  We'll take 3 days to do this 34 mile section.  I had mostly uphill climbs today.  When I got to Chestnut Knob Shelter I decided to stealth camp.  It is an old brick building that was formerly a ranger house.  It smelled bad and it was very hot inside and there were no windows.
I'm all by myself at the campsite and all I can see are trees and a campfire ring.  Another tough day so I'm going to bed early (before dark).  I think water may be a problem tomorrow.  I didn't cook dinner tonight because I didn't want to use any water.

Was on the trail by 7:30 after a good night's sleep.  I wanted to get on the trail early because where I camped was off the AT, on a blue blazed trail and if BBT came by early today I might miss him which would mean I wouldn't know where the car was parked.
It was a long climb first thing this morning as usual.  I was running low on water but not panicing yet.  BBT met me around 11:00 and we exchanged information.  I warned him about the shelter and the water situation.
About an hour later I ran out of water.  I asked a hiker who was headed the same direction if he had any extra water and he was out too.  About an hour later 2 guys that I'd camped with a couple nights ago came by going SOBO.  They had plenty of water and gave me half a liter and offered more but I said no.  There were no water sources until mid afternoon.  I was so glad to get there.  Seems like all you can think about when you're out of water is how thirsty you are.
Was planning to stay at Jenkins Shelter but somehow I walked right past it.  Another hiker said he did the same thing.  The next place to camp was 4.4 miles further but by the time I realized I'd missed the shelter I was halfway up an 800 ft. climb and not about to turn around and go back down.  So I got to camp around 5:30.  I had sore feet, sore legs, and needed more water.  There's a big creek across the road from the campsite so I've been drinking water all evening and have plenty for tomorrow.

Slept well but very tired after 2 long days.  Weather was beautiful, sunny and warm.  Since I only had 7 miles to do today didn't start hiking until 8:15.   Not very many hikers on the trail today.  Wonder where all the day hikers that are usually out on the weekends are???  
A funny thing happened yesterday.  I was just about to answer nature's call...I had just stepped off the side of the trail behind a bush because I was so tired and didn't see any large trees nearby.  I also hadn't seen any hikers for a couple of hours.  Had just started to unsnap my pants when around the bend come 2 hikers.  I quickly pulled my shirt back down and just stood there.  I was so glad I had been facing their direction or boy would they have gotten a view!  They apologized and I said I just hadn't found a big tree that I felt like walking to.  The girl said that sometimes it's harder to deal with things like that than you would think.  She is certainly right...especially for women.  That was a close call!!
Finished my hike around 12:30 and the car was waiting for me.  There's a small store right there so I went in and the clerk says it's closed, he'd just opened to give ice cream to the kids from the church across the street but if I needed something to drink he'd sell it to me.  Thank you!!  I was so hot, tired and thirsty.
Drove into Bland and picked up drinks for BBT and headed to the Pavilion on VA 42 to wait for him.  After an hour he arrives and we go to the Big Walker Motel to rest.  We go to Wytheville to do laundry and have some dinner.  Feels good to take a shower and have clean clothes.

Spent the day in Wytheville at the Red Roof motel.  Ran a few errands and ate lunch at the KFC buffet.  A couple of hours later bad things started happening to our stomachs.  Not sure it was due to the food but could have been.
Spent the rest of the day relaxing.  Planning to do a 13 mile slackpack tomorrow.

I still didn't feel well in the morning and BBT's leg was still sore so we decided just to skip the slackpack and drive to Harpers Ferry.  I'm taking the train to Rhode Island tomorrow to visit my sister and her family for a week then we'll head to Maine to hike for the rest of June and July.
Got to the Teahorse Hostel around 2:45 and had to wait for check-in at 3:00.  BBT is driving on to Maryland to plan his hike for the rest of VA.
Went to the AT Conservancy to pick up a map for No Worries and had dinner at Mena's Pizzaria.  Hadn't eaten much today but feeling better and hungyy, so had the special -- 6 in. sub, fries and drink for $6.99.  The meatball sub was delicious as were the fries.  Caught up on emails and walked back to the hostel.  Organized my pack for the train trip tomorrow.  Now I'd better get some sleep.

Travel day from Rhode Island to Gorham, NH.  Rob, from Yvonne's hiking club, drive us.  Took us about six hours with a couple of stops.  Thanks so much, Rob!!  Checked into the Barn Hiker's Hostel on the edge of town.  We stayed in the bunk house which didn't have bunks but comfortable beds with linens.  It was actually the loft of an old carriage house.  Rosie Red (Yvonne) and I walked into town for pizza and a stroll around town.

Our shuttle left at 7:30 and we were on the trail by 8:00.  Right off the bat we were faced with baldfaced slanted  rocks.  I fell 4, 5, 6 times or more.  I lost count.  I was definitely not prepared for that.  I'm not having any fun.
We arrived at the campsite and pitched our tent.  Only one other hiker is camped here.  I must have forgotten the ground cloth for the tent so we had to improvise with a piece of Tyvek that we use to cover our packs at night.  We had a peaceful night but we heard rain.   Bummer!

When we woke up and opened the tent flap,  we were surprised with dry surroundings.  Must have been dew falling from the trees that we heard last night.  There was a lot of fog which burned off soon.
We started hiking and immediately had to navigate more rocks.  It was just too much for me and I had a meltdown.  I told Rosie Red that I wanted to go home.  She calmed me down and encouraged me.  So I continued on, not that I had any choice.  We were in the middle of nowhere and no way to get out but to go forward.
We met a hiker from Germany and talked a few minutes.  She was SOBO so we parted in opposite directions.  A couple of hours later Wind Chime caught up with us and introduced himself and asked if we"d lost a ground cloth.  He handed it to us and said a female hiker had found it on the trail and figured it belonged to a NOBO hiker and asked him to see if he could find its owner.  I must have dropped it yesterday when I fell and the hiker we met this morning found it and gave it to Wind Chime.  We were so glad to have it back.  Thanks to both hikers!
Rosie Red had an encounter with the muck.  She was going through a boggy area and she lost her balance off a rock and stepped in muck that sucked her boot in all the way to the top of her sock..  When she took a step to get it out, her boot stayed in the muck and her foot almost came out of her boot.  This caused her to stagger like a drunk for about four steps before she regained her balance.  Her boot was covered in muck.  Oh yuck!
I was feeling a little more confident late afternoon but took another tumble.  This time I scraped my elbow and had to take off my pack to get up.  This part of the hike is not going well.  Rosie Red is doing great but I'm struggling.  We stopped at Gentian Pond Shelter and this was Rosie Red's first nite in a shelter.  She isn't any fonder of them than I am, but it will keep you dry.  Rain was in the forecast so we didn't pitch the tent.  There were only 3 of us in the shelter and Wind Chime set up his hammock nearby.  The water source was down a huge rockface and I had had enough so Rosie  Red went down to get the water.  She was a trooper because the bugs were biting horribly and she had to get a lot of water so neither of us would have to go back down there (like I could have gone down).
The view from the shelter was gorgeous.  I didn't sleep well and was up at 5am taking pictures.  (The birds in ME start chirping at 4:30 am when it gets light.)   We even had to go up a rock to get to the privy.

This was an 11.5 hr. day to only go 5.2 miles.  We didn't even stop for lunch because there had been a couple of periods of rain but we wanted to beat the heavy showers expected.  The rocks were horrible and got worse as the day progressed.  The last rock jumble of the day almost did me in.  It was raining and everything was wet and slick.  Several young hikers passed us by and one of them tried to help me thru a bad area.  At one point I got my foot stuck and he couldn't figure out how I should move to get it unstuck.  He got me thru it but I could tell he was anxious to move on.  Again Rosie Red got me through the day and I know she was exhausted from having to encourage me at every turn.  Even bootie scooting didn't work in some places.  
When we got to the shelter it was almost full but everyone started moving things to make room.  It was still raining but we checked out the tent sites and decided to pitch.  We had already decided to spend the next day drying out our gear and knew it would be easier at the tentsite.  We managed to get the tent pitched without getting any rain inside and we didn't cook dinner but ate snacks from our food bags.  We both slept well except Rosie Red's air pad had started losing air last night and went completely flat a couple of minutes after she blew it up tonight.

The rain had stopped by morning and we started pulling everything out that was wet and strung a clothesline to hang it on.  We spent the day keeping things in the sun so they would dry.  We went down to get water and just as we returned it started sprinkling.  We were grateful that we made it back in time to grab all our stuff before it got wet again.
We made the decision to get off the trail and skip Mahousic Notch.  This area is known as the worst mile of the whole trail.  I'm definitely not ready for that.  It was going to be a long walk to get out, but that's what we had to do.
